pred_note:
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
 Judy Gomez, a patient with psoriatic arthritis, came to the doctor's office to continue her ongoing management. During the conversation, it was revealed that Judy was doing good since the last visit, but there were some days when she had to take an extra prednisone for pain in her feet. The doctor recommended discontinuing the use of prednisone since it is causing more harm than good. Additionally, Judy reported that methotrexate helped with her joint pain but interfered with the COVID vaccine.  
PHYSICAL EXAM
 The doctor conducted a physical exam and found that Judy had some joint pain and bruises that showed up from prednisone use. The doctor recommended discontinuing the use of prednisone, which might relieve Judy from the prednisone-related bruises. Additionally, the doctor found ridges in Judy's nails from psoriasis.  
RESULTS
 The results showed that the treatment was progressing well, and Judy needed to stop prednisone and continue with methotrexate. She needed to get a blood test done before her next visit.  
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN
 Based on the conversation, the assessment was that Judy's psoriatic arthritis was progressing well, and the plan was to discontinue prednisone and continue with methotrexate. The doctor recommended a blood test for Judy. Follow-up is scheduled for three months.

gt_note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Psoriatic arthritis management.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Judy Gomez is a 61-year-old female who presents to the clinic today for ongoing management of psoriatic arthritis.

Ms. Gomez is currently taking methotrexate and prednisone 1 mg daily. She believes methotrexate has been relieving her joint pain.

The patient reports she has been doing well since her last visit. She has been able to decrease her prednisone dose to 1 mg daily; however, she took 2 mg for a couple of days due to increased pain in her bilateral feet.

The patient states when she received her first COVID-19 vaccine she held her methotrexate and felt "horrible" all week until the next Wednesday when she took it. She felt better by the end of the week. She did not hold methotrexate for her second COVID-19 vaccine.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Musculoskeletal: Full range of motion. Dystrophy of all the nails of the toes.

ASSESSMENT

• Psoriatic arthritis.
• High risk medication use.

PLAN

Psoriatic arthritis.
Stable on methotrexate and prednisone 1 mg daily. The patient will discontinue prednisone and continue methotrexate.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up in 3 months.

The patient reports she has been doing well since her last visit. She has been able to decrease her prednisone dose to 1 mg daily; however, she took 2 mg for a couple of days due to increased pain in her bilateral feet.

The patient states when she received her first COVID-19 vaccine she held her methotrexate and felt "horrible" all week until the next Wednesday when she took it. She felt better by the end of the week. She did not hold methotrexate for her second COVID-19 vaccine.
Musculoskeletal: Full range of motion. Dystrophy of all the nails of the toes.

• Psoriatic arthritis.
• High risk medication use. Psoriatic arthritis.
Stable on methotrexate and prednisone 1 mg daily. The patient will discontinue prednisone and continue methotrexate. The patient will follow up in 3 months.
